title: Identification & Authentication
description: Verify identities of users and processes

item.text: What is the status of making sure all employees, devices, and automated tools that use your systems have unique IDs so you can tell them apart?

valueCoding.display: Fully implemented – Every employee has their own login, devices are uniquely identified, and automated tools are tracked.
Partially implemented – Most users/devices have unique IDs, but some accounts are still shared or not clearly identified.
Not implemented – Users or devices share accounts, or there is no way to uniquely identify who/what is accessing systems.

item.text: Do you keep a list or spreadsheet of all company devices (computers, phones, servers, etc.) that connect to your systems?
How do you verify a person’s identity before giving them access to company systems?

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
Service Accounts are special logins used by software or automated tools, not people. Keep them limited to only what’s necessary and review them regularly to prevent misuse.

Device Inventory tracks every device that connects to your systems — like laptops, desktops, and phones. This helps ensure only approved, secure devices are used for work that involves government contract information.

item.text: Every computer, phone, or server should have a unique identifier so you know exactly which device is connecting. How do you uniquely identify each device that connects to your systems?

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.
Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any

simple
Any additional notes, remediation plans, or implementation challenges...

Identification (IA) requires assigning a unique ID to every user and device so that access to systems and Federal Contract Information (FCI) can always be linked to a specific, authorized individual.

•   Unique User IDs: Each employee or contractor must have their own login account.
•   No Shared Accounts: Prevents confusion and makes activity traceable.
•   Device Identification: Computers, phones, and servers should also have unique identifiers.
•   Account Lifecycle: Add new IDs only when needed and remove them promptly when no longer in use.

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

item.text: What is the current status of the controls that verify that users and devices are who they say they are before giving them access?

valueCoding.display: Fully implemented – Every user has a unique login and password (no shared accounts), default passwords are replaced, and all devices are authenticated before access.
Partially implemented – Most users and devices are verified, but some shared or default accounts/devices are still in use.
Not applicable – No systems in scope store or process FCI.

item.text: What methods do you use to confirm a user’s identity before they can log in?

valueCoding.display: Username and password – The most common method; each employee has a unique login and password.
Multi-factor authentication (MFA) – Requires two or more proofs, such as a password plus a code texted to your phone.
Smart cards / PIV cards – Physical cards employees insert or tap to log in.
Biometric authentication – Uses fingerprints, facial recognition, or other personal traits.
Digital certificates – Software-based “ID cards” that prove a device or user is trusted.
Single sign-on (SSO) – One secure login gives access to multiple company applications.

Password Requirements define the rules for creating strong passwords so accounts are harder to guess or break.

•   Length: Require a minimum of 8–12 characters (longer is stronger).
•   Complexity: Use a mix of uppercase, lowercase, numbers, and symbols.
•   Uniqueness: Do not reuse old or common passwords.
•   Protection: Never share passwords or store them in plain text.

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

item.text: Multi-factor authentication (MFA) means using more than one proof of identity before someone can log in. For example, a password plus a code texted to your phone, or a password plus a fingerprint scan. Do you use MFA?

valueCoding.display: Yes, for all users and systems

item.text: How do you handle default usernames and passwords that come with new systems or software?

valueCoding.display: Always changed before deployment – IT changes default logins before the system is ever used.
Changed during initial configuration – Defaults are replaced when the system is set up, but not necessarily before deployment.
Users required to change on first login – The system forces a password change the first time someone logs in.
No formal process – Default credentials may remain in place, creating a serious security risk.

item.text: Number of failed attempts before lockout:

extension.valueString: Enter notes or supporting evidence, if any
Provide details, explanations, or supporting documentation for your responses including links to drives or repositories where evidence is stored.

Authentication Failure Handling defines what happens when someone enters the wrong login credentials multiple times. This prevents attackers from guessing passwords repeatedly.

•   Account Lockout: Lock accounts after a set number of failed attempts.
•   Timed Delay: Add a waiting period before more login attempts are allowed.
•   Alerts: Notify administrators if repeated failures occur.
•   Reset Process: Provide a secure method for users to unlock or reset their accounts.

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.

Any additional notes, remediation plans, or implementation challenges...

Authentication (IA) ensures that users prove their identity before accessing company systems or Federal Contract Information (FCI). This prevents unauthorized access, even if someone knows a username.

•   Passwords: Require strong, unique passwords that are not shared between accounts.
•   Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA): Add extra steps like codes, apps, or tokens for sensitive systems.
•   Session Controls: Lock accounts after failed login attempts and log users out after inactivity.
•   Account Security: Change default credentials and disable unused accounts.

If you require assistance at any point, please utilize the “Ask AI” feature or contact a member of the Opsfolio CaaS team for expert support.
